Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who have accomplished the precepts, who have accomplished good precepts, and who have accomplished the precepts of benefiting sentient beings, should first fully learn the precepts of upÄsakas, Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras, and bhiká¹£us.
If it is said that one who has not fully accomplished the upÄsaka precepts can obtain the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era precepts, there is no such case.
One who has not fully accomplished the Å›rÄmaá¹‡era precepts and obtains the bhiká¹£u precepts, there is also no such case.
One who has not fully accomplished these three kinds of precepts and obtains the bodhisattva precepts, there is also no such case.
It is like a four-storied tower, the levels of which are sequential. Without reaching the second level from the first level, there is no such case;
Without reaching the third level from the second level, and without reaching the fourth level from the third level, there is also no such case.
Having perfected the three kinds of precepts, the bodhisattva who wishes to receive the bodhisattva precepts should sincerely give away all inner and outer possessions without attachment;
if one is unable to give them away, one will not have perfected the three precepts and will ultimately be unable to obtain the bodhisattva precepts.

At that time, the recipient should contemplate their own body as if observing with wisdom. At that time, in a quiet place, they should pay homage to the buddhas of the ten directions, kneel with their right knee on the ground facing east in front of the image, join their palms together and say:
Virtuous ones, buddhas of the ten directions, and assembly of bodhisattvas, listen!
I, so-and-so, am seeking the bodhisattva precepts.
I have already perfected the precepts of an upÄsaka and even the duties of a wise one, therefore I seek the bodhisattva precepts from the assembly of buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions.

Now the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions observe my mind. If I have no faith, if I have a mind that slanders the mind of enlightenment, if I have an evil mind or a deceitful mind, do not bestow the precepts upon me;
if I do not have them, then bestow the precepts upon me out of compassion.
Repeat this a second and a third time.
Diligently remain silent and single-mindedly contemplate, and say this:
Now you have bestowed upon me the bodhisattva precepts.
I have already obtained the bodhisattva precepts.
Why is this?

The buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions observe my mind with their knowledge of others' minds. Since I have a sincere mind, they should know that they have bestowed the precepts upon me out of compassion.
Now I have no teacher, but the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions are my teachers.
Repeat this a second and a third time.
At that time, the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions will immediately manifest signs, and you should know that you have obtained the precepts.
The buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions will tell the great assembly:
In that world, so-and-so has truly received the bodhisattva precepts. I have now bestowed them out of compassion.
Now this person has no teacher, but I will be their teacher. I now protect and think of them. They are my Dharma siblings.
Then they will rise and pay homage to the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions. This is the self-ordination.
If a wise person, out of arrogance, does not receive it, they do not obtain the bodhisattva precepts.

If the precept-breaker is in a distant place, if the country is in chaos, if one is seriously ill, if it is for the benefit of many people, if there is no other place to receive it, whether ordained or lay, if one is able to give up and give, deeply vowing to seek supreme perfect enlightenment.

At that time, if there is someone with the same bodhi mind, the same Dharma and the same understanding, who is able to teach and explain well, the person who wishes to receive the precepts should go to them, bow their head to their feet, bare their right shoulder, touch their right knee to the ground, join their palms, and say:
Virtuous One, listen carefully!
I now beg the Virtuous One to bestow the bodhisattva precepts, the great sovereign precepts, the unsurpassed precepts, the invincible precepts.
Virtuous One, if you do not take me seriously, please bestow the precepts on me out of compassion.

If the great virtuous one silently listens, one should then rise, re-arrange one's robes, face the Buddhas of the ten directions and three periods of time, the Bodhisattvas dwelling on the grounds, bow one's head, praise the merits of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas according to one's wisdom, single-mindedly contemplate the Three Jewels, kneel in front of the Buddha image with palms joined, and say:
Great virtuous one!
I, so-and-so, now request to receive the Bodhisattva precepts.
Great virtuous one!
Now, please bestow the Bodhisattva precepts out of compassion.
If the great virtuous one silently listens, the recipient should then single-mindedly contemplate the Three Jewels, give rise to a joyful mind, and think:
Now I have attained the immeasurable, boundless, unsurpassed treasure of merit and virtue, and will receive the precepts upheld by the Bodhisattvas.
One should then remain silent with a focused mind.
At that time, the wise one should say to the recipient:
Good man, listen attentively!
Dharma brother bodhisattva!
Are you now truly a bodhisattva?
Have you truly given rise to the bodhi mind?
The recipient replies:
Virtuous one!
It is indeed so.
The wise one further says:
Do you now possess the three kinds of precepts?
The reply is:
Complete.
He further asks:
Can you give up all inner and outer possessions?
The reply is:
I can give up.
He further asks:
Do you begrudge your body and wealth?
The reply is:
I do not begrudge.
He further asks:

Can you receive from me all the bodhisattva precepts, uphold all the precepts of the path to bodhi, and benefit all sentient beings? These precepts are like the precepts of the buddhas and bodhisattvas in the ten directions and three times. Can you uphold them?
The reply is:
I can.
The second and third [questions] are also like this.
At that time, the wise one should proclaim these words:
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions, the Sangha of great virtue, listen!
Now so-and-so seeks me and requests the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions to bestow the Bodhisattva precepts upon him.
He has already perfected the three precepts, given rise to the bodhi mind, is a true Bodhisattva, and is able to give away all internal and external possessions, not sparing his body and life.
I pray that the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions, out of compassion, will bestow the Bodhisattva precepts upon so-and-so.

Out of compassion, bestow the precepts, which are a treasure trove of immeasurable, boundless, unsurpassed merit, in order to benefit sentient beings and to increase the Dharma of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas.
The second and third [requests] are also like this.

At that time, a cool breeze will arise from the ten directions. The wise one should know that the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions have already bestowed the precepts upon this person. He should tell the recipient:
So-and-so, listen attentively!
The Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions are now bestowing the precepts upon you.
Just as all the bodhisattva precepts of the three times, you should uphold them with utmost sincerity.
Are you able to uphold them?
He replies:
Able.
The second and third [recitations] are also like this.
At that time, the wise one respectfully bows to the Buddhas and Bodhisattva Saá¹…gha of the ten directions, and also bows to the Buddha image. After bowing, he proclaims these words:
The greatly virtuous Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions listen!
Now, when so-and-so has recited three times, he has already received the bodhisattva precepts from the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the ten directions.
The one who speaks is myself, and the one who receives is so-and-so. I am the witness for so-and-so.
The great teacher refers to the Buddhas and Bodhisattva Saá¹…gha of the immeasurable ten directions, and the junior teacher refers to my own person.
There are two kinds of teachers:
1. The visible;
2. The invisible.
The invisible ones are the Buddhas and Bodhisattva Saá¹…gha of the ten directions;
The visible one is my own person.
Whether the teacher is visible or invisible, this person has completed receiving the precepts.
The second and third [recitations] are also like this.
In this way, the karman is completed.
When the karman is completed, both [teacher and student] remain silent.
At that time, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas of the worlds in the ten directions, knowing this sign, tell the great assembly:
In that world, there is such a person who receives the Bodhisattva precepts from that wise one.
Such a person is my Dharma brother. I now sincerely pity and protect him.
Because the Buddhas and Bodhisattva Sangha of the ten directions pity and protect him, both the giver and receiver increase wholesome dharmas.
After remaining silent for a short while, they then rise and respectfully bow to the Buddhas and Bodhisattva Sangha of the ten directions.
This is called the Bodhisattva having already received the Bodhisattva precepts.

All precepts, unsurpassed precepts, boundless precepts, precepts of the aggregate of merit, precepts of tranquil mind, precepts of pure mind, precepts that destroy the afflictions of all sentient beings - such precepts surpass the precepts of all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas in the ten directions.
Why is this?
Because it liberates all sentient beings.
After a bodhisattva has received the bodhisattva precepts, he should study and read the bodhisattva canon and the bodhisattva vinaya.

When a bodhisattva wishes to receive the bodhisattva precepts, they should first observe whether the other person has faith. If they do not have faith, one should not receive from them. If they are stingy, greedy, or discontented, violate precepts, defile precepts, do not respect precepts, delight in greed and anger, have no patience, are unable to prevent others from committing offenses, are lazy, indulge in worldly pleasures, delight in speaking of worldly matters, are unable to think of the Three Jewels for even a moment, are shrouded in doubt and ignorance, are unable to read and recite the bodhisattva canon and the bodhisattva precepts, and give rise to slander, one should not receive from such a person.
After receiving the precepts, one should not speak of them to those who lack faith, up to and including those who slander the Mahayana.
Why is this?
If those who lack faith, due to this cause and condition, fall into hell, therefore bodhisattvas should not speak of it to them. If they do speak of it, they incur an offense;
Bodhisattvas definitely know that if they speak to them, they can destroy those people's evil speech, evil actions, and lack of faith, and there is no fault in speaking.
After the bodhisattva has received the bodhisattva precepts, the teacher should explain to them the precepts and transgressions.

If they know that the bodhisattva is able to receive them with utmost sincerity, not receiving them for the sake of offerings, not receiving them for the sake of imitating others, and not receiving them for the sake of arrogance, then the teacher should explain to them the precepts and transgressions:
So-and-so, listen carefully!
The bodhisattva precepts have eight grave dharmas.
The four grave [precepts] are as previously [explained].

If a bodhisattva, out of greed for profit and offerings, praises themselves, saying they have attained the bodhisattva precepts and abide in the bodhisattva stages, this is called the fifth grave precept for a bodhisattva.

If there are those suffering in poverty and distress, as well as the sick who come to beg, if a bodhisattva is stingy and does not give even a single coin's worth of goods, and is stingy and does not give even a single verse of Dharma to those seeking the Dharma, this is called the sixth grave precept for a bodhisattva.

If a bodhisattva is angry, he should not do evil. If he hits with his hand, or with a stick or stone, or scolds with foul language, or if he is powerless and cannot hit or scold but harbors anger and resentment, or if he is beaten or scolded by others and the other person seeks to repent but he does not accept their apology and thus harbors resentment that grows without cease, his mind is impure. This is called the seventh grave offense for bodhisattvas.
If there are fellow students who slander the bodhisattva's vaipulya Dharma treasury, accept and uphold what is not the Dharma, one should not live with them;
if one definitely knows this, one should not praise their virtues to others. This is called the eighth grave offense for bodhisattvas.
There are two kinds of bodhisattvas:
first, the lay;
second, the monastic.
The lay have six grave offenses, the monastic have eight grave offenses.

If a bodhisattva commits any of these eight grave offenses, if he commits them completely, he will not be able to adorn immeasurable unsurpassed bodhi in the present, and he will not be able to make his mind tranquil in the present. He is then called a bodhisattva in name only, not a bodhisattva in meaning.
He is called a candala bodhisattva, not a Å›ramaá¹‡a, not a brÄhmaá¹‡a, and cannot correctly head towards unsurpassed perfect complete enlightenment.
The bodhisattva mind has three levels: lower, middle, and upper. If one commits the last four grave offenses with a lower or middle level mind, it is not called an offense;
If one commits them with an upper level mind or an evil mind, it is called an offense.

The upper level refers to one who delights in committing these four things, has no sense of shame, does not know how to repent, does not see the offense, and praises those who violate the precepts. This is called an upper level evil mind offense.
Even though a bodhisattva commits these four grave offenses, he still does not lose the bodhisattva precepts.

It is like a bhiká¹£u who commits the four grave offenses and loses the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts. If a bodhisattva commits the four grave offenses of a bhiká¹£u, they also lose the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts and defile the bodhisattva precepts.
Defilement means that in the present they cannot adorn bodhi, and do not attain immeasurable merit and samÄdhi. This is called defilement.
There are two causes and conditions for losing the bodhisattva precepts:
First, regressing from the bodhi mind;
Second, attaining an evil mind.
Apart from these two conditions, even in the next life in the hells, animal realm, or hungry ghost realm, one will never lose the bodhisattva precepts.

The bodhisattva precepts are not the same as the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts. If a bodhisattva receives the bodhisattva precepts again in the next life, it is not called newly attaining, but is called revealing and purifying.
Now I will further explain the characteristics of committing and not committing, and the differences in severity of the bodhisattva precepts.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, does not make offerings of flowers and incense to stÅ«pas, images, sÅ«tras, and those who recite them during the day or night, is unable to praise them, does not rejoice in them even for a single thought, this is called a grave offense, but not one of the eight grave offenses.
This is called a bodhisattva's defiled mind, a mind of doubt, a mind that falls into a wound and gives rise to impurity.
If one does something without a respectful mind, due to lack of faith or laziness, this is called a grave offense, but not one of the eight grave offenses.
If one lacks mindfulness, this is called a minor offense.
Not an offense: if one has a pure mind and always seeks enlightenment.
A pure mind is like the four kinds of faith possessed by a stream-enterer.
If a bodhisattva is insatiable and has few desires, but is attached to offerings, this is called a grave offense, but not one of the eight grave offenses.
Not an offense: if one is able to definitely know that insatiability can tame sentient beings.

If a bodhisattva sees an elder of high virtue, a fellow student, or a fellow teacher, and out of arrogance or malice does not rise to greet, bow, offer a seat, or engage in conversation with a welcoming attitude, or if asked about doubts, does not explain, this is called a grave offense, but not one of the eight grave offenses.
This is called a bodhisattva's defiled mind and doubtful mind, with a wound that falls and does not rise, and is impure.
There is no offense if one is sick, sleeping, or in a state of mental disturbance.

If one is attentively listening to the Dharma, making offerings to the Buddha, copying scriptures, reciting, explaining, discussing the meaning, or speaking with a guest who has just arrived, protecting the mind of the speaker, knowing that speaking will not lead to taming, in order to prevent the rules of the Sangha and to protect many people.

If a bhiká¹£u listens to the bodhisattva precepts in order to find faults, and those who do not believe or accept, those who do not believe or teach, and those who do not accomplish the precepts of an upÄsaka, do not accomplish the precepts of a Å›rÄmaá¹‡era, and do not accomplish the precepts of the PrÄtimoká¹£a, should not listen to the bodhisattva precepts. The listener commits an offense.

If a bhiká¹£u commits a pÄyantika offense, and without shame or remorse listens to the bodhisattva precepts, he commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense.ğŸ”½If a bhiká¹£u commits a sthÅ«lÄtyaya offense, and without shame or remorse listens to the bodhisattva precepts, he commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense.
If a bhiká¹£u commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense, and without shame or remorse listens to the bodhisattva precepts, he commits a pÄrÄjika offense.
That is to say, if there is one who speaks of the eighth grave [offense], he commits a saá¹ƒghÄvaÅ›eá¹£a offense.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says like this:
'Those who do not believe should not listen, and those who do not believe should not speak.'

If a faithful patron comes to invite the Bodhisattva to their home, a stupa, a monastery, a village, or a country, to provide necessary clothing, food, bedding, and medicine, if the Bodhisattva out of arrogance, anger, or contempt does not go to accept it, they commit an offense. This offense is committed due to afflictions.
If a Bodhisattva goes to a layperson's home alone without a companion, they commit a mistaken offense.

If they arrive at a layperson's house and are unable to expound the Dharma, reveal and teach it, and cause them to make offerings to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha, it is called committing a grave offense, but not one of the eight grave offenses.

There is no offense if they are sick, dull-witted, insane, have been invited far away, the road is dangerous, if they know that not accepting the invitation will lead to their being subdued, if they have already accepted an invitation, if they are diligently cultivating wholesome dharmas, if they wish to hear the meaning of what has not yet been heard, if they know the host's mind is not sincere, if they fear that accepting the invitation will anger many people, or if it is a monastic rule.

If a patron offers gold, silver, pearls, agate, lapis lazuli, crystal, male and female slaves, carriages and horses, elephants, horses, and various colored bedding to the bodhisattva, the bodhisattva should accept them. If he does not accept them, he commits an offense. This offense is committed out of affliction.

There is no offense if he is insane, if he knows that after accepting them he will definitely give rise to craving and attachment, if he knows that after accepting them the patron will regret it, if he knows that after the patron has given them he will become insane, if he knows that after accepting them the patron will become impoverished, if he knows that the items belong to the Three Jewels, or if he knows that the items were obtained through robbery;
if he knows that after accepting them he will obtain much suffering, such as royal difficulties, theft, death, imprisonment, evil reputation spreading, or being banished from the country;
if he knows that after accepting them he will be unable to give them away and cultivate merit in a good field of blessings.

If there are sentient beings who, in order to understand the meaning, wish to hear the Dharma, and they approach a bodhisattva to inquire about what they have not heard, but the bodhisattva, with a light or arrogant mind, does not explain it for them, they commit an offense. This offense is committed due to afflictions.

There is no offense if they know that the person in front is a person of evil and deviant views seeking to find fault, or if they are sick, or if they have just recovered from an illness, or if they are insane, or if they know that by not explaining it will lead to their being disciplined, or if the Buddha has not yet established a rule, or if they know that the person in front does not have reverence for the Three Jewels, or if their movements are coarse and rude, or if they know that they are of dull faculties and will give rise to wrong views upon hearing the profound meaning, or if they tolerate wrong views, or if they know that after hearing it they will turn to evil people and proclaim it, destroying the true Dharma.

If there are evil people who are able to kill and harm, as well as untouchables, if a bodhisattva does not associate with them, go back and forth with them, or explain the right Dharma to them, they commit an offense.
Why is it so?

If a bodhisattva sees someone who is keeping precepts, diligent, pure in body, speech, and mind, but does not give rise to compassion, or if they see an evil person and are able to give rise to compassion, then the bodhisattva will commit an offense if they do not speak.

There is no offense if they are insane, if it is a royal decree, if it is a monastic rule, if they fear that many people will be displeased, or if they know that by not speaking they will be able to tame the other person.
If there is a layperson who is not a relative, whether a householder or a brahmin, who offers various robes to the bodhisattva, the bodhisattva should accept them.
If the bodhisattva themselves seek and obtain many, they should also accept them.ğŸ”½As with robes, so it is with alms bowls.
As with robes and alms bowls, so it is with thread.
If a bodhisattva goes to the side of a layperson seeking thread and has a non-relative weaver weave it, instructing them to weave it tightly, making it broad and thick,
thinking, 'I will not wear it myself, but if you give it to the layperson, both of you will have merit.'
If the layperson says:
'I am doing this for the sake of the teacher, I only wish that you would wear it yourself.'

If the bodhisattva receives it and goes to the weaver himself, instructing them to weave it tightly, making it wide and thick, and if he obtains the robe and wears it himself, he commits a grave offense, but it is not considered one of the eight grave offenses.
If he does not instruct [the weaver], he does not commit an offense.
If a bodhisattva has received the bodhisattva precepts, he should receive and keep silk bedding, up to hundreds of thousands of pieces, and also gold and silver.
The disciples of the Buddha only benefit themselves, therefore the TathÄgata does not allow them to receive and keep [such things].
The bodhisattva is not like this, he benefits sentient beings, therefore he is allowed to keep [such things], but he must not not receive [them].
If he does not receive [them] for the sake of contentment and fame, he commits an offense of wrongdoing, falls, and does not rise up, has something to do, has doubts, and is impure.
If a bodhisattva commits an offense due to laziness and is unable to benefit sentient beings, he commits an offense, and this offense is committed out of delusion.

If a bodhisattva is praised by others as being at the ten stages, or as an arhat up to a stream-enterer who is content with few desires, and silently accepts it, he commits an offense. This offense is committed due to afflictions.
If a bodhisattva, when entering the assembly, sees people acting improperly or laughing, and does not admonish them, he commits an offense.
There is no offense if he is listening to the Dharma, in order to subdue them, in order to follow their minds and speak the Dharma, or in order to benefit them.
If one says:
'The bodhisattva does not delight in nirvÄá¹‡a nor does he not delight, he is not afraid of afflictions nor is he not afraid.
Why is this?
Because he transmigrates through birth and death.'
If a bodhisattva speaks like this, he commits an offense.
Why is this?ğŸ”½The bodhisattva delights in nirvÄá¹‡a, which cannot be known by the hearers and solitary realizers.
The nirvÄá¹‡a that is delighted in by the hearers and solitary realizers is not even one-hundredth, one-thousandth, one-hundred-thousandth part of the delight in nirvÄá¹‡a of the bodhisattva.
Bodhisattvas reprimand and fear afflictions, which Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas cannot know.
The reprimand and fear of afflictions by Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas is not even one-hundredth, one-thousandth, one-hundred-thousandth part of the reprimand and fear of afflictions by bodhisattvas.
Why is this?
ÅšrÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas only benefit themselves and cannot benefit others.
Bodhisattvas are not like this, because they benefit both themselves and others.
Although bodhisattvas practice with outflows, they are still superior to arhats. Even if they dwell in outflows all day, afflictions do not defile them, so they do not commit offenses.
If bodhisattvas do not fear evil reputations and do not protect against evil reputations, they incur an offense of wrong action.
If they falsely accuse others of evil when they are not evil, they incur an offense of wrongdoing. This offense is committed due to afflictions.
If they use harsh words to subdue others, they incur an offense of wrong action, but it is not an offense of wrongdoing.

If one does not violate this precept, it is like reprimanding non-Buddhists who deceitfully come to receive the bodhisattva precepts, or if one's mind is originally without evil and one's mouth speaks evil words, or if one is insane, or if one knows that reprimanding will bring great benefit, or if one knows that the other person will benefit from being angry, or if one protects the precepts and does not give rise to anger, or if one knows that the other person will gain a little benefit in the present but no great benefit in the future from being angry.
If a bodhisattva strikes in return when struck, scolds in return when scolded, or torments in return when tormented, they commit an offense of wrongdoing. This offense is committed out of affliction.
If there are bodhisattvas who criticize each other, whether truthfully or not, the bodhisattvas should immediately lower themselves and apologize. If they are unable to do so, they commit an offense.
Not accepting an apology is also an offense.ğŸ”½Lazily not apologizing is an offense.
Lazily not accepting an apology is an offense.

If a bodhisattva knows that the other person is by nature malicious and always looking for people's shortcomings, or if he knows that accepting would cause the other to break bad habits, then there is no offense.
If a bodhisattva harbors anger and resentment towards others, constantly thinking:
'If I see them, I will beat them or scold them,'
and does not let it go, and is unable to control himself, then he commits an offense.
If a bodhisattva travels the same road as a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«, there is no offense.
If there is a greedy mind, he commits an offense.
There is no offense if it is for the sake of taming [them].
If a bodhisattva accepts food from a bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä« who is not a relative, there is no offense.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattva mahÄsattvas, having given rise to the bodhi mind, have no one among sentient beings who is not a relative.
If a bodhisattva, out of greed, makes many disciples, he commits an offense.
There is no offense if it is for the sake of taming [them], or for the sake of protecting the Dharma, or for the sake of benefiting [others], or if there is no greedy mind.
If a bodhisattva is lazy, indolent, not diligent, and delights in sleeping, they commit an offense.

There is no offense if they are sick, if they are recovering from an illness and their strength has not yet returned, if they are traveling a long distance, if they are tired from reading and reciting, or if they are contemplating remedies.
If a bodhisattva engages in worldly talk that is of no benefit, they commit an offense.

There is no offense if they explain when asked by others, or if they speak in accordance with the minds of others in order to subdue them, and they do so with a sincere mind without adding or subtracting.
If a bodhisattva, out of a mind of arrogance, does not consult their teacher or accept their teacher's instructions, they commit an offense.
There is no offense if they are sick, if they are insane, if they are ignorant, if they are very intelligent, learned, and wise in order to tame beings, or if they are in meditative absorption.
If a bodhisattva, when lustful thoughts arise, does not contemplate the remedies to quickly subdue and extinguish them, they commit an offense.
There is no offense if, although they contemplate the remedies, the power of their afflictions is strong and they are unable to extinguish them;
If one deliberately arouses lustful thoughts,
If a bodhisattva says:

Because the sÅ«tras and vinaya of the Å›rÄvakas cannot benefit sentient beings.'

There is no offense if they do not know that there is a bodhisattva canon.
If a bodhisattva does not read or recite the true sÅ«tras of the TathÄgata, but reads and recites secular literature, they commit an offense.
There is no offense if they do so in order to engage in debate and refute wrong views, or if they study two parts of the Buddha's sÅ«tras for every one part of non-Buddhist texts.
Why is this?
In order to know that the non-Buddhist scriptures are false teachings and the Buddha's teachings are true, in order to know worldly affairs, and in order not to be despised by worldly people.

If a bodhisattva hears about inconceivable matters in the Bodhisattva Canon and the ÅšrÄvaka Canon, but does not believe or accept them, saying they were not spoken by the Buddha, whether slandering himself or others, he commits an offense.
If a bodhisattva says:

'My wisdom is weak, my physical eye is impure, I do not see the TathÄgata's profound realm. The TathÄgata's realm is seen by the Buddha's eye alone, and only the Buddha can know it. The entire Dharma realm is beyond my reach.'
If one is able to contemplate in this way, this is called true practice.
The bodhisattva's patience and impatience are both non-offenses.
If a bodhisattva gives rise to anger and arrogance, saying 'My precepts, learning, and wisdom are all superior to yours,' he commits an offense. This offense is committed out of affliction.

Not violating means if it is to destroy wrong views, to destroy those who despise the Buddha's teachings, if it is to subdue their arrogant minds, to give rise to faith in those who have not yet believed, and to increase the faith of those who have already given rise to faith.
If a bodhisattva hears where the Dharma is being taught, but does not go to listen even for a distance of one yojana, he commits an offense.
If it is a light teaching, not going to listen is an offense. This offense is committed due to afflictions.
If one does not go due to laziness, one commits an offense of wrong intention.
Not violating means if one does not know, is not aware, or does not hear about it, if one is sick, or if one has just recovered from an illness and is not yet strong enough;
if one knows that the speaker is mistaken and is teaching incorrectly, fearing that the speaker will feel embarrassed;

if the teaching of one Dharma has no other meaning, if one is cultivating wholesome dharmas, if one is transforming sentient beings, if one does not understand the teaching, or if one is unable to remember it.
If a bodhisattva disparages a Dharma teacher, does not give rise to respect, does not praise their virtues, and laughs at their incorrect words and meanings, they commit an offense.
If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, does not engage in activities with sentient beings, they commit an offense.
Namely, if they do not go, come, enter, exit, protect property, reconcile disputes, perform various good deeds, or practice precepts, giving, and learning together, they commit an offense.

There is no offense if they are sick, if they do not know how to do it, if they are themselves engaged in important matters, if they have already promised to assist others, if they are themselves cultivating wholesome dharmas, if they fear the anger of many people, if they are joyful, deluded, or insane, if they know that not being the same can subdue them, or if it is a monastic rule.

If a bodhisattva disparages a Dharma teacher, scolds them, strikes them, laughs at them, and only relies on the words and phrases of their teachings without relying on the meaning, they commit an offense. This offense is committed out of affliction.

If a bodhisattva, after having received the bodhisattva precepts, is unable to follow the minds of sentient beings, they commit an offense, namely, in terms of practicing and cultivating good deeds while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.
If a bodhisattva, after having received the bodhisattva precepts, sees a sick and suffering person and is unable to care for them and serve them, they commit an offense.
There is no offense if they themselves are sick.
If they are powerless, they should widely encourage those who have the power to do so.
If the sick person has many relatives, if they are urgently cultivating the unsurpassed good Dharma, if they are already caring for another sick person, or if their faculties are dull.
As with sickness, poverty and suffering is also like this.

If a bodhisattva, after having received the bodhisattva precepts, sees evil sentient beings practicing evil dharmas and is unable to admonish and encourage them, they commit an offense of wrong conduct.

There is no offense if they know that this person has a good friend who is able to admonish and reproach them, if they know that they will not follow the advice when spoken, if they have reached the stage of understanding language, or if they have a harmful mind.
If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, keeps possessions the same as a layperson, they commit an offense of wrongdoing.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, should not use gold or silver vessels to receive food and drink, the copper vessels they keep should not be the same as those of laypeople, and they are not allowed to use wooden vessels or horn vessels. Using them is an offense.
Not an offense: if they lose their original vessels, if they are traveling and invited, or if they are seriously ill.
If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, does not remember kindness they have received, they commit an offense. This offense is committed out of delusion.
If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, receives kindness from others but is unable to repay it, they commit an offense.
Repayment should be done by upholding the precepts, diligently sitting in meditation, reciting scriptures, and doing things that please the donor to repay them.
Not an offense: if the donor does not accept it.

If a bodhisattva, after having received the bodhisattva precepts, sees a suffering person who has died, lost property, or been separated from relatives due to the king, thieves, water, or fire, he should go to them and console them by speaking the Dharma, and give them what they need according to his ability.
If he is unable to do so, he commits an offense.

There is no offense if he is not in control, if he himself is seriously ill, if he does not accept the request, if there is doubt or difficulty, if the king is angry with that person, or if it is a monastic rule.

If a bodhisattva, after having received the bodhisattva precepts, keeps disciples but is unable to seek from faithful donors the necessary robes, food, bedding, medicine, and dwelling places to provide for them, and also does not teach the Dharma and guide them from time to time, he commits an offense.

There is no offense if he knows that his disciples have great power, are intelligent and virtuous, have many donors, if they are non-Buddhists who deceitfully come to steal the Dharma, or if he knows that they cannot promote the Buddha's teachings.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, always praises the good deeds of others, if he conceals the virtues of others, he commits an offense. This offense is committed out of delusion.

There is no offense if the other person prohibits it, if he is confused and does not know, if he is seriously ill, if he fears others' disapproval, or if it is difficult to understand, like an Ämalaka fruit, etc.
If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, sits on a bed or bench that exceeds eight fingers, he commits an offense.
There is no offense if he is speaking Dharma, if he is accepting an invitation from a faithful donor, or if he is sitting in a non-Buddhist shrine.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, should be angry but is not angry, should scold but does not scold, should punish but does not punish, should expel but does not expel among disciples, he commits an offense. This offense is committed out of delusion.
He should be angry but is not angry, should scold but does not scold, should punish but does not punish, should expel but does not expel, he commits an offense.

Not an offense means if one knows that one's disciple is able to burn a stupa or temple, or commit a great evil, or kill one's teacher, preceptor, fellow student, preceptor's fellow student, parents, or if one is waiting for the right time, or if one is certain that for these reasons the Sangha will be destroyed, or if one knows that later one will feel ashamed.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, obtains great spiritual powers, and sees someone who should be frightened but does not frighten them, or sees someone who should give rise to faith but does not cause them to give rise to faith, they commit an offense.
Not an offense means if one knows that everyone has wrong views and does not believe in the Buddha's teachings.

If a bodhisattva, after receiving the bodhisattva precepts, always thinks with utmost sincerity and does not give rise to thoughts of transgression, and if they do transgress, they should immediately confess to others, namely those who are well-versed in the Mahayana and Hinayana teachings and are able to expound them well.
This is called the bodhisattva's all-encompassing precepts.
From the first ground of the bodhisattva, understanding the six perfections up to all precepts, all are the bodhisattva's precepts, which are called all precepts.
What the TathÄgata has not yet explained in the sÅ«tras for Å›rÄvakas, he now explains in the bodhisattva canon.
Why are they called all precepts?
Because they comprehensively explain the precepts for renunciant and lay practitioners, they are all precepts.
The difficult precepts are of three kinds:
First, when bodhisattvas have great freedom and immeasurable wealth, they are able to abandon it all and receive the bodhisattva precepts, which are called the difficult precepts.
Second, when bodhisattvas are in a time of crisis, they still do not allow the precepts to have the slightest flaw, let alone violate them, which are called the difficult precepts.
Third, although bodhisattvas follow sentient beings in walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, they always uphold the precepts without violating them, which are called the difficult precepts.
The four kinds of all self-precepts are:
First, receiving;
Second, nature;
Third, cultivation;
Fourth, skillful means.
Acceptance refers to the three karmas.
Nature refers to being together with the nature. Because the nature of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas is gentle,

The actions of body, speech, and mind are always well cultivated. Those who cultivate skillful means in the presence of innumerable buddhas and bodhisattvas, like bodhisattvas who use the four means of conversion to embrace sentient beings and teach them to cultivate the goodness of body, speech, and mind, are called the precepts of oneself.
The precepts of good people have five kinds:
First, to personally uphold the precepts;
Second, to teach others to uphold them;
Third, to praise the precepts;
Fourth, to joyfully praise those who happily uphold them;
Fifth, to repent without rest in one's mind if there are offenses. This is called the precepts of good people.
The precepts of all practices have thirteen kinds:
First, to make vows and dedicate them to nirvÄá¹‡a;
Second, to be vast;
Third, to be pure;
Fourth, to be joyful;
Fifth, to be unbroken;
Sixth, not pulling;
Seventh, firm and solid;
Eighth, necklace;
Ninth, true;
Tenth, meaning;
Eleventh, faith;
Twelfth, treasure;
Thirteenth, constant.
As for the precepts of the Å›rÄvakas, all wholesome dharmas are causes for supreme perfect enlightenment. This is called the precepts of all practices.
The precepts of exclusion are of eight kinds. Bodhisattvas should always think like this.
Just as I do not like death, all sentient beings are also like this. Therefore, one should not kill living beings.

Just as I do not like robbery, theft, greed, lust, harsh speech, lying, divisive speech, meaningless speech, beating and scolding with sticks and stones, all sentient beings are also like this. Therefore, one should not rob, steal, be greedy, lustful, speak harshly, lie, engage in divisive speech, meaningless speech, or beat and scold with sticks and stones. This is called the precepts of exclusion.
Bodhisattvas, even at the cost of their lives, will never violate these eight precepts.

The precepts for benefiting oneself and others means that bodhisattvas, in regard to the precepts, prohibit what should be prohibited and allow what should be allowed. If they do not prohibit what should be prohibited or allow what should be allowed, they incur offenses.

Bodhisattvas know that all sentient beings can be accepted or abandoned as appropriate. With pure precepts of body and speech, they always practice together with the perfection of giving, up to and including the perfection of wisdom. Such pure precepts benefit both oneself and others. This is called the precepts for benefiting oneself and others.

The precepts of tranquility means that from the initial acceptance of the precepts, one sincerely upholds them, for the sake of the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a and the fruits of the bodhisattva, not for the sake of one's body or life. This is called the precepts of tranquility.ğŸ”½When bodhisattvas are sitting, if they see a king or elder and do not rise, they incur an offense.
If they are already cross-legged, if they see a king or elder and do not kneel, they incur an offense.
If one's clothes are not in order and one sees the king or elder, and one's appearance is not proper, one commits an offense.
If the king or elder speaks evil words, and one praises them as one wishes, one commits an offense.
If one forcefully gives rise to doubt in a place where there is no doubt, one commits an offense.
If one does not give rise to doubt in a place where one should give rise to doubt, one commits an offense.

The bodhisattva precepts are such that one should not sleep in the first and last watches of the night, but should be well-wishing, well-acting, and fully endowed with the good Dharma, capable of being used in the middle, with right livelihood accomplished, far removed from annihilationism and eternalism, fully practicing the middle way, free from the pleasures of the five desires, unsurpassed and supreme, far removed from wrong views, unbroken and indestructible. This is called the precept of tranquility.

The bodhisattva precepts are accomplished, fully endowed with immeasurable wonderful fruits. Because of the causes and conditions of this precept aggregate, one is fully endowed with the perfection of morality.
Although the recipient has not yet attained anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, they have already attained the five merits:
First, they are always remembered by the buddhas and bodhisattvas;
Second, to experience constant pure bliss;
Third, to have no regrets at the time of death;
Fourth, to be reborn in the Buddha's world after leaving the body;
Fifth, to adorn supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Those who uphold the bodhisattva precepts do not do so for their own sake, but only to benefit others and adorn supreme, perfect enlightenment.

These bodhisattva precepts are all accomplished by the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the past, present, and future, as numerous as the sands of the Ganges River, and so are the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions.
